issues.description: The UML in the problem statement defines Ride.abbreviation as type String (UML: -abbreviation: String), but the solution implementation declares the abbreviation attribute as char in Ride and consequently uses char in related constructors and getters. This is a cross-artifact type mismatch: students following the UML/problem statement will implement abbreviation as String, while the provided solution/reference uses char, which can cause confusion and failing tests that check constructor signatures or attribute types.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the abbreviation type consistent across artifacts. Preferably update the solution (and template) to use String for Ride.abbreviation, adjust the Ride attribute, constructor parameter, and getter accordingly, and propagate this change to all subclasses/constructors (RollerCoaster, LaunchedDropdownTower, LaunchedRollerCoaster). Alternatively, update the UML/problem statement to specify abbreviation: char if that is the intended design.

issues.description: Constructor parameter types in the solution use char for the abbreviation parameter, but the problem statement requires constructors to match the UML attributes (which specify abbreviation: String). This creates a constructor-parameter mismatch: the required public constructors (in Ride, RollerCoaster, LaunchedDropdownTower, LaunchedRollerCoaster) should accept a String abbreviation according to the UML and task text, whereas the solution's constructors accept a char.
issues.suggested_fix: Align constructor signatures with the UML: change the abbreviation parameter type in the Ride constructor and all subclass constructors from char to String (and update assignment/getters). Alternatively, if char is intended, update the problem statement/UML and task text to explicitly state abbreviation: char so students implement the correct type.
